instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.AP_RESET_L: What is AP_RESET_L? AP_RESET_L resets the wifi hardware when it is low, which will keep it from working. AP_RESET_L needs to be high for reset to not be asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Hi,

stubborn board again. So I got it with not turning on problem. No liquid damage, but had replaced backlight IC before, the rest looks good. There is green and orange light on MagSafe, but fan doesn’t spin, just try to start and stops (Quarter fan spin). <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ~4v, not shorted. I‘ve checked the area of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>) and adapter current sensing resistors <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 were blown (resistance in kohm, the battery side was measuring 2,2ohm). I’ve replaced them along with ISL, resistance between <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 got 20ohm. After connecting adapter had no fan spin though PPBUS raised to 8,56v. It turned out, that adapter resistors blew again, so I’ve replaced ISL and resistors again. This time board started, so I decided to put it in topcase and test it. Another adapter connection blew the resistors again, PPBUS dropped to ~4v... I’ve checked all components on page 53 of schematic... <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> measures 20ohm, <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> are ok, <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> is ok... I’ve replaced all set again and tried with battery only - no reaction. I’ve tried with different MagSafe boards and I/O cables - it keeps burning these resistors and ISL... I’ve also checked voltage rails for shorts and haven’t found any... just because board started after one of ISL/resistors replacement I believe power rails are not the actual problem here. Do you have any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground at pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, as L7030 too.
Be sure no short between <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Pin 17 - [COLOR=rgb(184, 49, 47)]0,136v[/COLOR]
Pin 18 - [COLOR=rgb(184, 49, 47)]0,137v[/COLOR]
Pin 27 - 0,619v
Pin 28 - 0,579v

L7030 - [COLOR=rgb(184, 49, 47)]0,136v

I guess problem is here? [/COLOR]

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> not shorted.

EDIT: I've removed F7040 and applied 8,56v on pin 2, board is powering on, fan is spinning, CPU gets warm.

threads.message:
Do NOT do that again, as no reason.

"Pin 27 - 0,619v
Pin 28 - 0,579v"
You still have a problem with <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52, or traces.

Thank you for your support, I really appreciate it. I wish you good weekend, will get back to this on Monday ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message: I've plugged charger in and resistors blew again.. Resistance between pins 27/28 was 1,6kohm, PPBUS ~4,5v. Replaced all set again, first I got 8,3v on PPBUS and board was cycling (one of the coils clicked every half a second, couldn't recognise which coil exactly.), after repluging charger PPBUS went down to 4,5v again but <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 are OK (20,5ohm between pins). There should be short somewhere, but interesting thing is, that when I have applied 8,56v it started normally.. I will try to reflow SMC, but what else can it be? mosfets?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; pins 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.
Be sure to have 20 ohms between pins 27/28; remove <CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR>/22, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
After reflowing SMC and replacing ISL + resistos there was no change, board wasnt turning on, just clicking. PPBUS ~8,4v. It turned out, that L3895 is clicking, voltage on it was jumping between 0 and 2v. While I was measuring the board it suddenly started... I replugged the charger and again is started. I have connected display, SSD and it boots normally, loads OS. PPBUS without battery is 8,37v, with battery connected 8,56v. Was turning on both on battery and charger. After few minutes it turned off, and started clicking again... PPBUS 8,36v, current sensing is fine, 20ohm betwee 27/28. Here are readings you requested:

Pin 1: 0,003v (burned <RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR>, after replacing it burns again, 0,464v in diode mode on pin 2, OL on pin 1)
Pin 2: 16,15v
Pin 3: 4,35v
Pin 6: jumping 0,7v - 1,1v
Pin 9: 0,037v
Pin 12: 3,42v
Pin 13: 3,39v
Pin 14: 3,39v
Pin 15: 0,059v
Pin 17: 8,38v
Pin 19: 5,06v
Pin 20: 5,03v
Pin 27:16,10v
Pin 28: 16,10v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Run it on battery, until drain about 50%.
Then check if battery is charging.

threads.message:
"I've replaced <RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> and it blew up again"
Impossible, if you soldered correct 330K value.

Be sure to have correct resistors on board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message: I'm more than sure that it has correct value, I'm replacing it already third time and checking before and after soldering... I have just put new one there, it measured 330K. I plugged charger and board doesn't react, just clicking. I measure <RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> - blown, shows OL...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Considering the worst scenario, applying 20V on 330K resistor, means 0.06mA (60 microampers).
Do you really thing that resistor can get blown from such reason (1.2mW)???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message: Yes, you are completely correct, I don't argue with that. I just post here what is happening on this board. I put perfectly measuring 330K resistor, triple check it before plugging charger in. After I plug it in nothing happens. I disconnect charger, check that resistor and it's OL.... I've done it 2 more times now. every time putting 330k resistor..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message: Remove <CAPACITOR>C7085</CAPACITOR> and replace <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>/86, <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Everything done and checked triple before connecting charger. Board has green/orange light, clicking every half second with quarter fan spin. With charger only PPBUS is 8,37v, with battery 7,99v, with both is jumping 8,17v-8,56v. Current sense is OK, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pins 27/28 have 20,5ohm, 17/18 have 2,5 ohm.

<RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> was perfect 330K, after disconnecting charger it shows OL or 80K, after some time it's 330K again. This board is trolling me now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Capacitors from charger area maintain voltage some time.
Onboard measurments on ohm scale are not relevant untill these caps are discharged.
You've got confused and <RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> never got blown in fact.

Keep battery disconnected, untill get the board working correctly with charger alone.
Check diode mode to ground on all big coils; compare readings with known good board.
Be aware, as CPU coils can have low ohm value to ground as normal.

Do you get stable <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 66869, member: 682"]
You've fot confused and <RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> never got blown in fact
[/QUOTE]
That's right, I just wasn't waiting enough long to let caps discharge..

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 66869, member: 682"]
Do you get stable <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
[/QUOTE]
Yes, they both are stable 3,3v.

Some other readings:

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3,3v,
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0v,
<SIGNAL>AP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0v,
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> - 0v

Diode mode readings on big coils:

L9701 - 0,385v
L7260 - 0,366v
L3895 - 0,475v
L7220 - 0,400v
L7030 - 0,130v
L7100 - 0,007v (13ohm to ground), another board I have has 0,014v and 28ohm to ground
L7630 - 0,007v (13,9ohm to ground), another board I have 0,15v and 28ohm to ground
L7330 - 0,184v
L7550 - 0,001v (2,4ohm to ground)
L7510 - 0,001v (3,5ohm to ground)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Still quater fan spin now?
If yes, check for pulse at all big coils.
Also check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
SMC bypass mode changes something?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message: Yes, still quarter fan spin. All big coils except L7550 are pulsing. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0v, in SMC bypass mode fan spins once and stops, then again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message: Do not get any pulse at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, at same time coils pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
It's pulsing too, gets to 3,3v then drops. But board doesn't pulse every time I connect charger. Sometimes it just doesn't react at all, sometimes it's pulsing. 

While measuring <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R2584</RESISTOR> it turned on twice, behaving like while normal board start - CPU got warm, fan was speeding up because of no trackpad connected. After I took probe off <RESISTOR>R2584</RESISTOR> and touched it again, board turned off then started again. I replugged charger and now it's just pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
Random behaviour change is not easy to diagnose.
There could be broken trace/solder under some BGA chip.
Try reballing SMC first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 66927, member: 682"]
Try reballing SMC first.
[/QUOTE]
I've already done it in beginning of the thread. I'll relpace it this time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message: I've replaced SMC and it seems that it was the problem. Except first 2 tries when board didnt react for charger, now after SMC reset it seems OK - turning on, charging and working on battery, loading OS correctly. I will test it today and report if problem has been solved.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps burning current sensing resistors
threads.message: Replacing SMC solved the problem, computer works stable for few days already. [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] thank you for your help and patience! ;)
